text: I've seen some iterative solvers have errors that look like they are getting smaller exponentially with number of steps. Are the predictor corrector algorithms to speed up iterative solvers?

elements.text: I've seen some iterative solvers have errors that look like they are getting smaller exponentially with number of steps. Are the predictor corrector algorithms to speed up iterative solvers?

text: Krylov solvers already do the best they possibly can out of the krylov space - there's nothing you can do better than them using the same information they use

elements.text: Krylov solvers already do the best they possibly can out of the krylov space - there's nothing you can do better than them using the same information they use

text: For other types of algorithms you can, eg that's exactly what Anderson acceleration does

elements.text: For other types of algorithms you can, eg that's exactly what Anderson acceleration does

text: I probably should have mentioned that i saw in a presentation for Projected Gauss-Seidel

elements.text: I probably should have mentioned that i saw in a presentation for Projected Gauss-Seidel

text: Yeah, that's exactly why nobody uses gauss Seidel - it can be sped up by guessing the pattern of convergence, and that's probably one way to derive krylov algorithms

elements.text: Yeah, that's exactly why nobody uses gauss Seidel - it can be sped up by guessing the pattern of convergence, and that's probably one way to derive krylov algorithms

text: The presentation i saw was held in 2020 on the software runs on milliions of PCs, so it can't be that nobody uses it at all.

elements.text: The presentation i saw was held in 2020 on the software runs on milliions of PCs, so it can't be that nobody uses it at all.

text: You'd be surprised how many papers come out saying "we replaced this crappy Jacobi method with a conjugated gradient algorithm"

elements.text: You'd be surprised how many papers come out saying "we replaced this crappy Jacobi method with a conjugated gradient algorithm"

text: I don't know about projected gauss Seidel, but straightforward gauss Seidel is worse than a krylov method

elements.text: I don't know about projected gauss Seidel, but straightforward gauss Seidel is worse than a krylov method

text: Any algorithm that can be written as a fixed point algorithm *should* be sped up using Anderson acceleration

elements.text: Any algorithm that can be written as a fixed point algorithm
should
be sped up using Anderson acceleration

text: The presentation in question was about the constrained rigid body mechanics in the game Roblox: <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=P-WP1yMOkc4> I'm in no position to evaluate it. Since i couldn't even begin to implement it.

Straight convergence plot = missed opportunity

text: Thanks for the input, i'n now rewatching the video and am not seeing the plot i thought i was when i watched it last time ...

Maybe it was in some game dev blog.
Thank you for helping me understand that thing though.

text: Well, "best" is not well defined :p mininal residual norm is not the minimal error norm, so you could in principle create a method "better" than gmres

elements.text: Well, "best" is not well defined :p mininal residual norm is not the minimal error norm, so you could in principle create a method "better" than gmres

text: I also learned today that it matters where you put the error. If you can somehow contain the error in a subspace orthogonal to the one you are interested in, it can also work really well.

elements.text: I also learned today that it matters where you put the error. If you can somehow contain the error in a subspace orthogonal to the one you are interested in, it can also work really well.

text: <@U6N6VQE30> I have still to find out a case where that matters, in practice it doesn't seem to matter too much which criterion you minimize as long as you minimize something

elements.text: I have still to find out a case where that matters, in practice it doesn't seem to matter too much which criterion you minimize as long as you minimize something

text: <@U9MD78Z9N> to some extent that is linked to preconditioning : if you know that some components of the error are more interesting than others, you can use that as a metric (and therefore as a preconditionner)

elements.text: to some extent that is linked to preconditioning : if you know that some components of the error are more interesting than others, you can use that as a metric (and therefore as a preconditionner)
